abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement plan for the Guangdong
            Pearl River Delta Urban Environment Project for China
            discusses the terms of involuntary resettlement in
            connection with the reconstruction of a drainage pipe
            network, affecting an area covering five administrative
            regions. It discusses the number of household affected, the
            amount of land acquired, the agricultural workers affected,
            and the costs of resettlement allocated. Measures to
            minimize resettlement impacts include: optimizing the route
            of the pipe network, using pipe-jacking technology, reducing
            the construction period and temporary resettlement costs for
            project affected people (PAPs), and reducing the closing
            period for enterprises and shops. The four subprojects,
            Dashadi, Liede, sewage networks, and the solid waste
            disposal center are examined in separate volumes.  In
            general, compensation and rehabilitation measures will
            include: timely compensation, restoration of attached
            structures, tax relief for expenses, job creation, priority
            employment given to young adults who are rural PAPs,
            psychological counseling and skill training, house
            relocation fees, replacement costs for structures, and
            non-natives will be able to rent nearly identical land for
            fish breeding and poultry raising. The project will pay
            special attention to vulnerable groups such as the elderly
            (without children), widows, single-parent families, the
            disabled, the chronically ill and destitute, and will
            periodically monitor their conditions.
